awd_titl_txt: Centering minoritized high school students' perspectives from introductory Computer Science through 12th grade and beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite advances made by national Computer Science (CS) for All movements, women, students of color, and lower-income students are still underrepresented. Prior research has shown that computer science learning should be engaging, meaningful, and relevant for all students. This is especially true for underrepresented youth who may need additional support to develop a sense of belonging and identity with computing. This project looks closely at how and why students perceive their computer science courses during their high school years. The investigators will interview minoritized youth in Los Angeles and Mississippi high schools to learn what makes a difference for their engagement, sense of belonging, and agency with computing. The work will also study how underrepresented students do or don't persist from introductory to more advanced computing curricula.

This research will fill two significant gaps in current knowledge. First, youth perspectives have mostly been missing from conversations regarding keeping equity at the center of computing education. This work will specifically amplify minoritized students' voices. Second, the research will collect needed longitudinal data regarding the longer-term impacts on students' personal and educational pathways following experiences with new high school curricula, including Exploring Computer Science and Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles. The researchers will investigate how minoritized youth can best be supported to feel a sense of belonging in CS fields. This work will shine a light on the nature of the persistent under-representation of women and Students of Color in computing, moving the field toward critical solutions to this problem. This project is funded by the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Great efforts have been made to broaden participation in computing toward ensuring that all students are prepared with the knowledge and skills to critically engage and create with today’s rapidly evolving technologies. Encouraging all students to learn computer science not only ensures that more students have opportunities to pursue the still unknown computing jobs of the future, but also that more diverse perspectives are at tech design tables. Increased diversity of ideas will improve the computing technology we use to solve problems today, and may help prevent the development and negative impacts of biased algorithms, artificial intelligence systems, etc.. More community members understanding what computer science is and how it works may decrease the number of people swayed by misinformation and cybersecurity infringements so that the general public is better positioned for civic participation and improved quality of life. 

However, considering the nationwide low enrollment of high school students in computer science courses today, how can we support sustained engagement and interest in computing among young people? What aspects of curricula and pedagogy encourage students to want to study computer science, feel that they belong in the field, and feel that they can apply what they learn to their lives (along any career pathway)? 

In this project, we turned to students directly to share answers to these pressing questions. Who better understands what young people need and want in their educational experiences today than young people themselves? And, more specifically, we sought to elevate the voices and perspectives of young people coming from communities historically underrepresented in computing in order to understand what they experienced as both barriers and supports to their computing education. We met students across three different regions of the US (west coast, midwest, and deep south). Along the west coast, we have been able to longitudinally follow Black and Latine students who experienced CS for the first time in 9th grade all the way to 2024, during which almost all are studying in 4-year colleges and community colleges. 

From this work, students have shared with us: 1) students from communities historically underrepresented in CS are keenly aware of social and political current events impacting our daily lives and they want their computer science education to speak directly to how computing technology intersects with these events; 2) more specifically, student interest and engagement in computing increases when given an opportunity to learn about and consider the ethical impacts of computing on the world, especially when educators engage pedagogy that centers socially responsible computing; 3) students also believe that computing education must prepare students to both understand and be able to address issues of equity, ethics, and social responsibility in CS. Thus, students want computing courses to center topics such as biased AI, impacts of misinformation on democracy, cybersecurity issues, etc., while openly addressing issues of racism, sexism, and the underrepresentation of women and people of color in computing; 4) students who identify as CS people have experienced more opportunities to work on CS projects they found meaningful or important, and opportunities to see the relevance of CS to their everyday lives. Those who did not identify as CS people did not have these opportunities in their classrooms; and 5) engagement with computing education increases when teachers show support, care, and respect for their students, as well as personal passion for computer science. 

Some of these findings have been translated into a story format through the graphic novel entitled Power On! (Ryoo & Margolis, 2022, MIT Press). This book follows the lives and experiences of four high school students from diverse backgrounds as they confront the harm technology has done in their own community. They awaken to how technology can perpetuate racism and inequality and gradually understand that the lack of diversity in computing companies results in technologies that do not reflect the voices and perspectives of themselves: women, people of color, LGBTQ+, and immigrant communities. In response, the four friends seek out computing experiences that are both personally and politically empowering, and decide to use what they’ve learned to take a stand for all students to learn computer science.
